data.scheme_name:
80IAC- Exemption To Start-ups
56 (2) (VIIb)- Taxability of Share premium Deferment of tax liability in case of ESOPs
79- Carry forward and set off of losses in case of Start-ups 54EE- Exemption from tax on Long-term capital gains2
data.benefits:
1. 80IAC: Tax Holiday to startups. 

2. Section 56(2)(viib): Ensures fair valuation of investments in startups to curb money laundering. 

3. Section 79: Allows eligible startups to carry forward and set off losses despite changes in shareholding.
data.eligibility:
1. Section 80IAC: - Registered startup with DPIIT (DPIIT certificate holder). - Should be in the first 10 years of Incorporation - Annual turnover must not exceed ₹100 crore in any financial year. 

2. Section 56(2)(viib): - Applicable to companies receiving investments from Indian investors at a value obver and above the fair market value of shares. - Exemption is available for DPIIT-recognized startups that comply with the specified conditions and file Form 2. 

3. Section 79: - General Rule: Losses can be carried forward only if at least 51% of voting rights remain with the same shareholders. - Relaxation for Startups: Recognized startups can carry forward losses despite changes in shareholding, provided original shareholders holding shares during the loss year continue to hold shares in the set-off year.
data.conditions:
1. Section 80IAC: - Must be engaged in innovation, development, deployment, or commercialization of new products, processes, or services driven by technology or intellectual property. - Should apply and get approved a tax exemption certificated from the CBDT 

2. Section 56(2)(viib): - File Form 2 with CBDT, where startup should declare that funds are not used for buying shares, securities, or land.
data.beneficiaries:
1. Section 80IAC: - Registered startup with DPIIT (DPIIT certificate holder). - Should be in the first 10 years of Incorporation - Annual turnover must not exceed ₹100 crore in any financial year. 

2. Section 56(2)(viib): - Applicable to companies receiving investments from Indian investors at a value obver and above the fair market value of shares. - Exemption is available for DPIIT-recognized startups that comply with the specified conditions and file Form 2. 

3. Section 79: - General Rule: Losses can be carried forward only if at least 51% of voting rights remain with the same shareholders. - Relaxation for Startups: Recognized startups can carry forward losses despite changes in shareholding, provided original shareholders holding shares during the loss year continue to hold shares in the set-off year.
data.prerequisites:
1. Section 80IAC: - Must be engaged in innovation, development, deployment, or commercialization of new products, processes, or services driven by technology or intellectual property. - Should apply and get approved a tax exemption certificated from the CBDT 

2. Section 56(2)(viib): - File Form 2 with CBDT, where startup should declare that funds are not used for buying shares, securities, or land.
data.context: Sections 80-IAC, 56(2)(viib), and 79 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 provide for deductions for start-up profits, taxation of certain capital receipts like share premiums, and conditions for carrying forward and setting off company losses with continuity in shareholding.
data.description:
1. 80IAC: Tax Holiday to startups. 

2. Section 56(2)(viib): Ensures fair valuation of investments in startups to curb money laundering. 

3. Section 79: Allows eligible startups to carry forward and set off losses despite changes in shareholding.
data.how_to_apply: Claim by filing Income Tax Return and other specific forms/submissions of respective sections
data.checklist_info_a:
1. PAN
2. Aadhar
3. Create an account in the Income Tax website
